video.title: Debugging JavaScript - Are you doing it wrong?
video.description:
Learn a better way to debug your JavaScript.

Video from WellPaidGeek. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCejtQthQXQpZs3-kZCqsbrg

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Linda Scoon
topLevelComment.text: This video is 4 years old  and I've not seen this video .  Life could have been so much easier better late than never I guess

topLevelComment.author: Ken Taylor
topLevelComment.text: Whatttt!!!! Thank you

topLevelComment.author: Muhammad Zaakir Mungrue
topLevelComment.text: This video makes no sense, how did the App magically load itself into the browser ? Apparently he started teaching before the video started and he did not realise that the video had not yet started !!!  LOL How could you give a tutorial and the most important part of the tutorial was completed before the video even started and why is this so popular ? This is not a tutorial this is just you showing a different way to use the the debugger

topLevelComment.author: Pennyworth
topLevelComment.text: lol...I can finally sleep

topLevelComment.author: whereismycheese 54
topLevelComment.text: console.log -> debugger!

topLevelComment.text: 😜 😂 console prints 😬

topLevelComment.text: Thanks♡

topLevelComment.author: FrankCoding
topLevelComment.text: Cool stuff. I was also working a modern review of debugging with console object in JavaScript :)

topLevelComment.author: Low Frequency
topLevelComment.text: What os are you using ?

topLevelComment.author: Aromal Anil
topLevelComment.text: freeCodeCamp has helped me a lot in my way. And now I have got a new piece of knowledge !

topLevelComment.author: Christian Lanoire
topLevelComment.text: That’s the way to explain, right to the point, you deserve to be well paid :)

topLevelComment.author: H G
topLevelComment.text: Freecode camp reinforces console.log() debugging through their curriculum unfortunately! Should have people using the real debugger from the get-go and should also teach debugging before they get beyond basic javascript!

topLevelComment.author: shabblabbat wababbalat
topLevelComment.text: Good lord, haven’t ever used a console.log in 15 years, just set a breakpoint.  Who’s teaching these codemonkeys these days, philosophy majors?

topLevelComment.author: Kevin Deason
topLevelComment.text:
Better way? I highly doubt this is a statement we can assert as fact. It most definitely is a good way but not in all instances a better way.


If I wanted to inspect every item in a for/foreach loop I would much rather just log the data than inspect it through the dev tools as per the video. It will be faster.

Each method has it's own merits

topLevelComment.author: 별자리TV
topLevelComment.text: Thanks for teaching this way and I will use console. log

topLevelComment.author: gopher
topLevelComment.text: Logging is good way to find problem

topLevelComment.author: rajashekhar
topLevelComment.text: Coverage,  performance, animations, sensor in chrome

topLevelComment.author: The Pup
topLevelComment.text: console.log() fan club represent!!

topLevelComment.author: Dima Tonkih
topLevelComment.text: That's all good and can be used in someway, but, i think, breakpoint's in devtools are more usable anyway.

topLevelComment.text: Does this work for Angular Typescript too?

topLevelComment.text: Wonder if this works in node

replies.author: WellPaidGeek
replies.text: If you have the browser setup correctly and run the node app with --inspect, then yes!

topLevelComment.author: demfak •
topLevelComment.text: good to know, I was going crazy with console.logs

topLevelComment.author: Chaaos2
topLevelComment.text: Very cool

topLevelComment.author: Aleksandr Vysockij
topLevelComment.text: Didn’t know about this. Thank you. Will try it out!

topLevelComment.author: GammaEspeon
topLevelComment.text: Wouldn't it be better to just set a breakpoint in the developer tools rather than adding anything into the code to force it? That way you wouldn't have to go back and extract the debugger command later, particularly if you have several of them lying around within the code.

replies.author: ooo ooo
replies.text:
I agree. When you're used to classic dev such as Java, C#, C and the like the IDE takes care of it all. But here we work on a browser. The flow is not exactly the same.
I knew times I dreamt of such tools.

replies.author: medicore0000
replies.text: WebStorm has this functionality where you can add the break point by just clicking the appropriate line number. Just like in the dev tools. No need to write that debugger line and remove it later.

replies.author: Hashim Warren
replies.text: I heard people mention this technique but never saw it demonstrated. Than you! Very clear!

replies.author: Replica
replies.text: I agree with the above. Changing code to do debugging in general is a bad practice. Chrome debugger works relatively well with the source maps and all that jazz without needing this. Slippery slope of weird coding practices. It's a nice trick but we'd have years of slowly replacing leftover console.logs to start replacing leftover these language specific debugging statements.

replies.author: WellPaidGeek
replies.text: I see what you mean, but at the same time you'd have to navigate to the right place in the sources tab within the developer tools, so it's easier to initially add the first breakpoint within your IDE, since you'll probably already have the offending code open in there. A linter should pick up stray debug statements. But yes, what you're proposing is still a viable alternative.
